Show HN: Cross-region network routing of websockets with Fly.io's built-in proxy
text:
Hi, I've recently had a chance to dig into using Fly.io's builtin proxy[^1] for cross-region network routing of HTTP calls and websockets.

This is especially useful if you're building collaborative experiences at the edge, such as a real-time chat, a multiplayer game, or a Figmadobe competitor (wink wink).

The demo works: https://fly-replay-header-demo.fly.dev/ -- the country flag visually confirms which instance you're connected to.

That being said, I made a couple fun mistakes along the way, so I figured I'd write up and share what I've learned. Suggestions for improvement are also welcome. Cheers!

[^1] https://fly.io/docs/reference/architecture/#fly-networking

Show HN: Inside A High School Hackathon – Assemble, August 2022
text:
Hi HN, I want to share this short documentary on a 183 person hackathon that I (age 17) ran with my friends this summer.

Coding changed my life. However, I've always struggled to find a space with folks my age who also find joy in coding, especially since the pandemic begun. My friends & I wanted to run an amazing in-person hackathon as soon as it was safe to do so, and Assemble was that event.

To try and help other teenagers organise their own hackathons, we’ve open sourced all of our planning documents - including finances, marketing emails, website code, run-of-show, etc - at https://github.com/hackclub/assemble.

Hoping that Assemble will resonate with people here, and happy to answer any questions about the organising process!

Ask HN: Should I open source my project?
text:
I'm thinking about open sourcing my project but there are multiple hurdles to this.

1. I have aws services including serverless, cognito, dynamodb, amplify on the project as the initial intention was not to open source.

2. The open source parts run on container services and kubernetes and the whole server side might be expensive for indie's to run just for the benefits of creating a conflict free schedule on google calendar

3. If I open source it, do I have to rewrite all the aws services into open source alternatives?

What do you guys think?

What are benefits vs risk?

I think there will be an increase level of trust if I open source but AWS services adds a whole lot of complexity for anyone to self host.

Plus V2 of the project (work in progress) which is a hybrid between clockwise and doodle would also be open source if I open source v1.

Ask HN: Best way to find help creating technical doc (open- or closed-source)?
text: Am looking for one-time help creating documentation (e.g. man pages, tutorials) for open source project (e.g. https://github.com/liquidaty/zsv) as well as product documentation for commercial products, but not enough need for a full-time job. Requires familiarity with, for lack of better term, data janitorial work, and preferably with methods of auto-generating documentation. Any suggestions as to forums or other ways to find folks who might fit the bill for ad-hoc or part-time work of this nature?

What Happened to the Now.sh Domain?
text:
I know it still exists and every .now.sh is redirected to the equivalent.vercel.app domain, but why did Vercel stop promoting it? To me it is a great choice for an app hosting service, with a number of famous apps on it already, such as carbon.now.sh and others. It is certainly better than herokuapps com, no?

So what am I missing here? Has there been some public information about this discussion?

Thanks
